titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the D. Cady Eaton Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Linda Wrigley

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 08:03

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Correspondence, notebooks, journals, lectures, drafts of articles and books, and other writings of D. Cady Eaton, art historian, social commentator, and professor at Yale. Included are a number of articles of a philosophical and satirical nature written for the New Haven Journal and Courier.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: D. Cady Eaton Papers (MS 4). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: I. Correspondence. II. Writings. III. Special Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The D. Cady Eaton Papers are divided into three series: Correspondence, Writings, and Special Files. The Correspondence series contains fifty-nine letters addressed to Eaton. Correspondents of note are Leonard Bacon (a prominent Congregational clergyman) and Noah Porter, president of Yale University.

The Writings series makes up the bulk of the papers. The material is divided into five sections: (a) Books, which served as a basis for the published works mentioned above, consisting of notebooks on modern French painting and sculpture; (b) Articles, of a philosophical, sometimes satirical nature, written for the New Haven Journal and Courier, usually signed "Periander," 1894-1895, 1897-1901, 1903, 1908, 1910; (c) Lectures on the history of art contained in approximately one hundred notebooks, mostly undated; (d) Journals pertaining to Eaton's travels in Europe, 1853-1854, and England, 1877-1878; and (e) Writings of Others, 1908, 1913-1914, n.d.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: D. Cady Eaton* (Daniel Cady Eaton) was born in Johnstown, New York, June 16, 1837, the son of Daniel Cady and Harriet Eliza (Cady) Eaton. He received his B.A. degree from Yale in 1860 and his LL.B. degree from Albany (New York) Law School in 1861. On December 17, 1861 Eaton married Alice Young. From 1861 to 1863 he served in the New York militia, retiring with the rank of colonel. Eaton practiced law in New York until 1866. From 1867 to 1870 he studied the history of art, first at the University of Berlin, and then in Paris. He was appointed Professor of History and Criticism of Art at Yale University in 1869, a position he held until he resigned in 1876. Eaton returned to Yale in 1902 and was made professor emeritus in 1909. He was the author of three books: Handbook of Greek and Roman Sculpture (1884), Handbook of Modern French Painting (1909), and Handbook of Modern French Sculpture (published posthumously in 1913). He died in New Haven May 11, 1912.
Additional biographical material may be found in Who Was Who in America , 1897-1942, Appleton's Cyclopaedia of American Biography , and the Yale Alumni Weekly , May 1912.
* Professor Eaton always used the initial D. in place of Daniel in order to distinguish himself from his cousin, Daniel Cady Eaton (1834-1895), a botanist and also a professor at Yale.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: In addition to his published books, the following printed pamphlets by D. Cady Eaton are catalogued as part of the collections of Sterling Memorial Library:
"Introduction to the Study of Greek Sculpture." An Address. (New Haven, 1878) (In Greek Archaeology , V. I)
"Introduction to the Study of Greek Sculpture," 1878
"Pensions." New Haven, 1893 (originally published in the New Haven Register
Report to Messrs. Bacon and Twichell, appointed June, 1875, committee to investigate the affairs of the Art School. (New Haven, 1875)
The Study of the Arts of design in American Colleges... New Haven, 1882
Yale College in 1881. Four articles by an "Alumnus" reprinted from the New Haven Evening Register
Yale College in 1890, Reflections on its charter, 1890

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by name. There are fifty-nine letters addressed to D. Cady Eaton, as well as approximately ten drafts of letters in Eaton's hand. The latter is at the end of the series.

did.unittitle: Drafts of Letters by D. Cady Eaton

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided into five sections: Books, Articles, Lectures, Journals, and Writings of Others. Under the Books section there are fifteen numbered notebooks on modern French painting and fourteen numbered notebooks on modern French sculpture, which are preliminary drafts of Eaton's books, Handbook of Modern French Painting (1909) and Handbook of Modern French Sculpture (1913).

In the Articles section there are forty-five pieces arranged alphabetically by title. These articles, dated between 1894 and 1910, represent the world situation as Eaton saw it. Most of the are signed "Periander" and are addressed to the editor of the New Haven Journal and Courier .

There are approximately one hundred notebooks in the Lectures section dealing with the history of art. The notebooks are arranged under the name of the country or the geographical area with which their contents deal. These headings include: "Egypt," "England," "France," "Germany," "Greece," "Italy," and the "Near East." There are thirteen notebooks in this section which are concerned with aesthetics and art forms. They are grouped under the heading "Miscellaneous." Most of the notebooks are undated.
The Journals section contains two items in Eaton's hand. The first records a trip to Europe in 1853-1854. The second records a sojourn in England from April 9, 1877 to June 1, 1878.
There are three items in the Writings of Others section.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Special Files series contains a certificate of life membership in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, college papers, an expense book, two catalogs of books, a reprint from the American Journal of Science , a sketch book, the May 1912 issue of the Yale Alumni Weekly, and notes on the Yale School of Fine Arts, Items in this series are arranged alphabetically by type.
